greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(1) = 0, and for n > 0, a(n+1) = floor(k / 3) where k is the number of terms equal to a(n) among the first n terms.
comment: In other words, for n > 0, a(n+1) = floor(o(n) / 3) where o is the ordinal transform of the sequence.
Every nonnegative number appears infinitely many times in the sequence.
The second difference of the positions of the zeros in the sequence appears to be eventually 6-periodic.
link: Rémy Sigrist, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Rémy Sigrist, Colored scatterplot of the first 10000 terms (where the color denotes the parity of n)
example: The first terms, alongside their ordinal transform, are:
program: (PARI) o = vector(7); v=0; for (n=1, 87, print1 (v", "); v=o[1+v]++\3)
xref: See A329982, A329984, A329985 and A330004 for similar sequences.
results.author: _Rémy Sigrist_, Nov 26 2019
